Based on the article "Building Identity Graphs over Heterogeneous Data", here are 10 important actionable ideas:

1. Identity graphs are powerful tools that allow organizations to connect data points from various sources to build a more comprehensive understanding of their customers.
2. By creating an identity graph, organizations can gain a better understanding of customer behavior, preferences, and demographics, which can be used to personalize marketing campaigns and improve customer engagement.
3. Identity graphs can be built using a variety of data sources, including CRM data, transactional data, online activity data, and third-party data sources.
4. The quality of the data used to build an identity graph is crucial. The data must be accurate, up-to-date, and standardized to ensure that the graph is reliable.
5. Machine learning algorithms can be used to build and maintain identity graphs, enabling organizations to automatically update and refine the graph over time.
6. Data security and privacy are important considerations when building and using identity graphs. Organizations must ensure that they are complying with all relevant regulations and best practices.
7. Identity graphs can be used for a variety of purposes, including fraud detection, risk management, and personalization.
8. Graph databases are a popular choice for storing and querying identity graphs due to their ability to handle complex, interconnected data.
9. Apache Spark provides a powerful platform for building identity graphs, thanks to its ability to handle large-scale data processing and its support for machine learning algorithms.
10. By investing in the creation and maintenance of an identity graph, organizations can gain a competitive advantage by better understanding their customers and improving their engagement and loyalty.

At Cox Automotive, we've built something called an identity graph. We're using these today to help our dealerships which are our clients, our clients' car dealerships, as well as automotive OEMs reach their customers today.

Let's dive into the agenda. First, I'm going to talk a little bit about Cox Automotive so you guys have the business contacts of everything that we'll be talking about. Next, we're going to talk about an ideal consumer journey. What I mean by that is what does the car shopping journey look like for the consumer? Specifically, what does it mean from the context of advertising and marketing? From there, we're going to talk about some of the challenges of realizing that ideal vision, specifically a couple of key takeaways for those of you attending.

One of the big challenges is tracking consumer identity across multiple data sets. The challenge there is consumers often have many different identifiers. Because of those many different identifiers, it's hard to know that they're all the same person. We're going to talk about how to bridge that gap. We're also going to talk about something called the post-cookie world. Specifically, what we mean there is using third-party cookies to track consumers across multiple different websites. We found that that doesn't work very well anymore. We're going to talk about what we've seen in our own login. Some of the approaches we've used to mitigate that.

We'll present the solution architecture of our whole solution that I mentioned before. We'll wrap up with some lessons learned both from creating an identity graph and using Amazon Neptune.
